intro.desc: I'm a software developer and an enthusiast of computer science and programming. I have spent the last four years earning a Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science to satisfy my long-running fascination with computers and to build functional skills for use in a career. Over the past several years I've spent in school I learned how to be effective at dedicating myself to filling gaps in my knowledge as I encounter them. My eagerness to impress drives my motivation to get better at everything I do.

bio1.desc: I have spent the past six years finishing my Associate's Degree and getting my Bachelor's in Computer Science. The courses for my major introduced me to the fundamentals of a broad range of computer science principles.

degree1.header: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

bio2.desc1: Outside of computers and programming I like to be in the outdoors. It can be a solo adventure to a new fishing spot, a few friends on a camping trip or boogie boarding in the freezing Pacific ocean-- and I'll be happy.
bio2.desc2: At home, if I'm not working on coding projects I like to read, draw, or build. Generally I prefer to spend my time either making something or moving around.

experience.intro: My work and programming experience includes code collaboration with peers, designing and building computer science course material and troubleshooting Linux infrastructure.

exp1.desc: My general responsibilities were to present short lectures on data structures to lower-level computer science students and be available during labs to help debug or answer conceptual questions.
list: Presenting and explaining data structure concepts to groups of students in labs
Guiding individual students to solutions for programming problems using C++
Developing and maintaining C++ code bases for use in computer science labs
Coordinating lab and lecture materials development with project management software
Proctoring student exams and coding proficiency demonstrations
Training new employees with debugging exercises and code discussions

exp2.desc: My participation in the Capstone project got me introduced to git workflows, front-end technologies and frameworks, and the beauty of collaboration.
list: Developing an interactive web application using Node and React with TypeScript
Data modeling for a graph data structure implemented with an MVC architecture
Scrum-like collaborative procedures with a team of peers
Collaborating with CI/CD using git and GitLab
Researching unfamiliar technologies for use in project development

exp3.desc: As a member of The Computer Action Team -the organization responsible for the technical infrastructure of Maseeh College of Engineering and Computer Science- I learned how to listen to users describe their IT issues and respectfully guide them to solutions. Much of our day-to-day responsibilities involved writing and running scripts in a Linux environment to gather information or solve problems.
list: Working directly with MCECS students and faculty for IT troubleshooting
Collaborating on revisions to technical documentation and website content
Attending weekly informational presentations on IT subjects

skills.intro: I am very open to learning new technologies and using best practices when coding and developing.

skill1.desc: C, C++, Python, Java, HTML, CSS, TypeScript/JavaScript, Bash Script, Rust, SQL

skill2.desc: Linux, Git, GDB, SQLite, PostreSQL, JSON, Regex

skill3.desc: C++ STL, ReactJS, NodeJS, Bootstrap, jQuery/AJAX

skill4.desc: Vim, VS Code, IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm

work.intro: Some of the below are assignments from coursework, others are personal projects. I tend to take on personal projects to gain familiarity with languages or libraries while solving some kind of problem.

proj1.desc1: An SPA web application for visualizing the effects of an individual's influence in a complex environment of personalities.
proj1.desc2: The project was built with ReactJS on NodeJS supported with graphics and animation using KonvaJS. We used an MVC architecture to organize our data structure interactions. Our development strategy was to use CI/CD where we each took on different development roles.
proj1.desc3: My contribution included implementation of a weighted, directed graph interface, modeling other data structures, animation rendering, and of course, debugging anything I could.

proj2.desc1: A command-based note-taking utility designed for people who spend a lot of time in a terminal.
proj2.desc2: With qnot the user can quickly add a tagged note to a local SQLite database, straight from the command line without opening an interface. Notes can also be created and edited with the user's default text editor.
proj2.desc3: Tagging notes is built in to the note-taking itself by allowing a '+' to be put before a word to turn it into a tag. Viewing and managing notes can be done via command line arguments and will open an interactive, command-based environment.

proj3.desc1: A text-based game of solitaire; playable in a command-line.

proj4.desc1: This is the repo for my answers to coding practice questions from various sources. Currently it contains a Roman numeral converter, a bubble sort implementation, a ransom note 'decoder', and a sliding window comparison.
